content.description: Start on an obvious rail near the entrance of the cave and traverse left through a series of overhanging crimps and side pulls. Climb up and traverse far left until you can safely exit the rail inside the cave.
content.protection: Make sure to bring lots of pads especially for the exit moves (a little sketchy)
content.location: In the large cave uphill and behind the stone hut. This is the boulder facing the wall with "Green Mountain Gringo / The Green Egg".

content.description:
A fun, core intensive, problem at the far back of the cave. 

  Start below the end of the traverse of GAD/WYWG in a shallow hole below a wide crack.  Fight the barn door and layback up the slightly overhanging crack to a fun fist jam move to gain the jugs.  Either drop off or top out.
content.protection: Multiple pads are help, as the fall into the hole isn't flat.
content.location: In the rear of the Smugglers' cave on the right wall.  Starting in the obvious hole.

content.description: Start on the big undercling. Go left to the arete and top out.
content.location: Above Shadows of Reality. (hike up past Biscuit a bit and you will see the roof coming out of the cave on the left

content.description: Start on an undercling on the roof. Do a powerful gaston move behind you into a huge undercling. Finish the stand start from here by going left to the arete.
content.location: If you are looking at the Shadows of Reality face, this is the roof up one level in front of you. Its on the way to Rhode Island Ripper.

content.description:
This used to be posted as "Out of the hole project" was recently sent by Aaron Neitzel and given this name. 

  Starts in a hole in the cave with 3 ways to get to it (see below). Use the underclings and high feet/toe hooks to start in the cave. Move out to the nice edge low on the face out of the cave, find feet to get a far right sidepull on the face.
content.location:
This is located in the main cave. You can enter by going in the Green Mountain Gringo side and going straight back and down into a hole towards the back right. 

  Also accessed by walking up past Biscuit. Walk into the cave where these two boulder's meet: 

mountainproject.com/v/bat-c… (right where the pad in the pic is *this is the best way in and there is plenty of room to squeeze in between the boulders*) 

  A third option is to hike up past the Bat Cave climb and take a left and find the face that comes out of the cave.

content.description: Start on some crimps left of squeeze lab in the roof (see pic) and move right through some holds that are facing you to get to the squeeze lab top out.

Start on a low right crimp and a higher left incut gaston. Stand up into an undercling, jack your foot up, match, and hit the lip and top out. Watch out for falling into the death pit on the right. A spotter can stop you. Also watch out for the pointy rock. Might have been done before long ago
content.location: Not in the cave but between the info hut and the main cave entrance. Its the overhung wall on the right of the main cave entrance. Far right side of the overhang where its shorter and cleaner on top.

content.description:
Sit start with your feet in the hole under the boulder(good sloping ramp for left foot) Make a big move out of the hole and then start heading left to a sloper and rail system. Match the left rail and Make a big move out right before toping out the boulder at its highest point. 

(This climb could be considered an eliminate as it climbs the holds on the left side of the face and was done originally without the left arete. It is easier if you use the arete)
content.protection: The landing looks terrible but with 4+ pads it’s quite safe.
content.location: Starts on the same holds as being green and climbs left finishing at the height of the boulder.

content.description: Although at first glance it looked like the holds were invisible and this line would be impossible the sequence ended up being really cool. Sit start just left of the arête on a diagonal rail. Make a couple hard moves up and left to some mediocre crimps and prepare for the crux iron cross that gets you into the V8 stand start. Sticking this move takes a massive amount of crimp strength and body tension. Continue traversing left and drop off around the corner of the cave as for Greening all Day.
content.location: Starts left of Greening all day.

content.description: Start matched on a jug near the entrance to the cave. Move left on a series of crimps, staying low until you reach a two-finger crimp. Make a hard deadpoint with the right hand and finish on a jug. This is a variation of While You Were Greening, which takes the higher line of holds.
content.protection: Pads and spotters. Slab is slippery, so dismount carefully.
content.location: In a cave up the hill directly behind the ranger kiosk.

content.description: Sit start with a right hand crimp on the right of the arete and a left hand sloping pinch on the arete. Make a hard move left to the arete and then make your way up the face and right.
content.protection: 2-3 pads and a spotter for the top out.
content.location: Head to the far back left end of the Green cave. Green Rhino climbs the left horn shaped arete on the left end of the block.

content.description: Before you freak out that this is already on MP hear me out. They're different problems."Lest one get the impression that Smuggler's Notch has no steep powerful problems, there is one drastic exception to this rule 50 yards uphill and left behind the stone bus shelter. Green Mountain Gringo (B1) hand traverses slopes and pockets for a body length and a half beneath the biggest roof around, then blasts another body length straight out the roof via a football-size quartz chunk to a nervous, landing-from-hell, one-chance-only slap to big holds a foot over the lip. GMG is as gripping as a doctor with a bone-saw and definitely out of character for the area." - John Sherman, Stone Crusade (1994)Andy Salo and I chatted with Bill Patton in the parking lot where he recounted the story of Verm cratering into the talus nearly splitting his head before lighting up a smoke and firing this climb next go like the legend he is. Intrigued by the story, confusion over the name Green Egg vs Green Mountain Gringo and the various exits, we went to check it out and try and formalize names, grades, etc.Turns out the OG Green Mountain Gringo is wicked good and deserving of more ascents. It's better, harder, and  scarier than Green Egg (which continues to traverse and exits more left where the roof is smallest). The lines share a start and some traversing but do not feel contrived and I think it's fitting that this climb has its' own entry. Verm kinda shits on the Notch in Stone Crusade but talks this climb up quite a bit.
content.location: As with Green Egg start on obvious start holds far right below the roof. Traverse left until you are under 2 pockets on the roof which you will use to "blast out the roof". The foot long finish holds over the lip are a helpful too in finding out how this climbs. Jugs abound above them to a high top out.

content.description: Sit start at the base of the left arete. Climb the triangle shaped face using the left arete and right facing rail systems. Top out at the height of the boulder. You will be near the base of Rhode Island Ripper when you top out.
content.protection: 3 pads is nice or a spotter to move pads this traverses quite a bit.
content.location: This starts directly behind the Green Rhino. Walk into the back of the "green cave" and walk behind the boulder that Being Green is on. This climbs the arete and right leaning slab/face.
Behind the stone hut near the entrance to the cave on the back side.

content.description: Start as for Sit to Greening all day. Do the same first move and use the same drop knee, from the drop knee get a gaston and move up off that to another gaston (or go straight to the 2nd one) and do a huge foot kick to the start for Greening All Day. Grab a pinch and bump to a high quartz pinch. Finishes on the jugs in the seam above as it cannot top out.

Stand tall and reach up to a suspended block. Right hand is a positive mini-pinch, left hand is a diagonal sloping incut to the left. Pull on ans campus up to a jug, get inverted and throw up a heelhook and move right on a series of sloping rails and pinches.After a few moves figure out how to reach up to some sloping dishes at the top. Stand on a large foot and grab a perfect handlebar root.
content.protection: Ideally 5-10 pads. Choosing to fall may not be a good idea.
content.location: This problem is located in the middle of the large cave. The start is above head height and the landing is one of the worst in the Notch. This line is directly behind "Not Easy Being Green".

content.description: Sit start on the large rail on the right end of the vertical block at the back left of the green cave. Make big moves to positive edges straight up the right end of the boulder.
content.protection: 2 pads the landing is a bit uneven.
content.location: Head into the Green cave all the way in the back left is a skinny vertical block. Green Eggs is the route on the right end of the face.

pathTokens: Boulders Behind the Main Parking Lot/Visitor Center

content.description:
An area holding a good number of great climbs, including John Sherman's Green Mountain Gringo, put up during his quest to boulder in all fifty states. 

  The name is mine, but seems fitting considering the naming scheme for the problems located here.  I'll change it if it's been getting called something else.
